nodes.text: The coronavirus cannot thrive in warmer climates.
The sensitivity and specificity analyses of ambient temperature and population size on the transmission rate of the novel coronavirus (COVID-19) in different provinces of Iran
On this basis and according to the latest epidemiological researches, both ambient temperature (AT) and population size (PS) can be considered as significant transmissibility factors for coronavirus.
Thus, there is no scientific reason to confirm that the number of COVID-19 cases in warmer climates is less than that of moderate or cold climates.
Spatial Model Of COVID-19 Distribution Based On Differences An Climate Characteristics And Environment Of According To The Earth Latitude
Spatio-temporal analysis of meteorological factors in abating the spread of COVID-19 in Africa

Africa, with a mostly relatively warmer temperature differs from other regions of the world and in addition, has recorded far fewer cases compared to Asian, Europeans and the Americans (North and South).
Susceptible supply limits the role of climate in the COVID-19 pandemic

Our results suggest that, in the absence of effective control measures, significant cases in the coming months are likely to occur in more humid (warmer) climates, irrespective of the climate-dependence of transmission and that summer temperatures will not substantially limit pandemic growth.
Correlation of ambient temperature and COVID-19 incidence in Canada
Many have speculated that, like SARS, the activity of SARS-CoV-2 will subside when the climate becomes warmer.
The effects of regional climatic condition on the spread of COVID-19 at global scale

It was found that most of the countries located in the relatively lower temperature region show a rapid increase in the COVID-19 cases than the countries locating in the warmer climatic regions despite their better socio-economic conditions.
Spatial modeling cannot currently differentiate SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus and human distributions on the basis of climate in the United States
Climate and seasonality influence the distributions of many diseases, and studies suggest a link between SARS-CoV-2 and cool weather.
One such study, building species distribution models (SDMs), predicted SARS-CoV-2 risk may remain concentrated in the Northern Hemisphere, shifting northward in summer months.
Still, we do find slightly more population scaled viral cases in cooler areas.
Spatial modeling could not differentiate early SARS-CoV-2 cases from the distribution of humans on the basis of climate in the United States
One such study, building species distribution models (SDMs), predicted SARS-CoV-2 risk may remain concentrated in the Northern Hemisphere, shifting northward in summer months.
We do find slightly more population-scaled viral cases in cooler areas.
Factors Affecting COVID-19 Outbreaks across the Globe: Role of Extreme Climate Change
